message.raw:
Moved daqmx reading to threads instead of gtk timeout callbacks. When they're doing nothing they're really doing nothing now, instead of while condition: pass or time.sleep or similar.

Appears to be working. Will now work on pushing the acquisition subprocess to being a subprocess of the hardware subprocess. But not to worry, the queues it will be writing into will go straight to the parent, without going through the process in the middle of the heirarchy.
message.html:
Moved daqmx reading to threads instead of gtk timeout callbacks. When they're doing nothing they're really doing nothing now, instead of while condition: pass or time.sleep or similar.

Appears to be working. Will now work on pushing the acquisition subprocess to being a subprocess of the hardware subprocess. But not to worry, the queues it will be writing into will go straight to the parent, without going through the process in the middle of the heirarchy.

Appears to be working. Will now work on pushing the acquisition subprocess to being a subprocess of the hardware subprocess. But not to worry, the queues it will be writing into will go straight to the parent, without going through the process in the middle of the heirarchy.

values.message:
Moved daqmx reading to threads instead of gtk timeout callbacks. When they're doing nothing they're really doing nothing now, instead of while condition: pass or time.sleep or similar.

Appears to be working. Will now work on pushing the acquisition subprocess to being a subprocess of the hardware subprocess. But not to worry, the queues it will be writing into will go straight to the parent, without going through the process in the middle of the heirarchy.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where printing to stdout and stderr would cause a crash because both streams were apparently a string ('nul').

This was caused because when running without a command window, all output is redirected to os.devnull to prevent the stupid windows crash where you cant write to stdout in the absence of the terminal. So I had redirected both streams to os devnul. Little did I know that os.devnull was a string, not a file descriptor, and I needed to open() it to get the file descriptor.
message.html:
Fixed a bug where printing to stdout and stderr would cause a crash because both streams were apparently a string ('nul').

This was caused because when running without a command window, all output is redirected to os.devnull to prevent the stupid windows crash where you cant write to stdout in the absence of the terminal. So I had redirected both streams to os devnul. Little did I know that os.devnull was a string, not a file descriptor, and I needed to open() it to get the file descriptor.

This was caused because when running without a command window, all output is redirected to os.devnull to prevent the stupid windows crash where you cant write to stdout in the absence of the terminal. So I had redirected both streams to os devnul. Little did I know that os.devnull was a string, not a file descriptor, and I needed to open() it to get the file descriptor.
summary.html:
Fixed a bug where printing to stdout and stderr would cause a crash because both streams were apparently a string ('nul').

This was caused because when running without a command window, all output is redirected to os.devnull to prevent the stupid windows crash where you cant write to stdout in the absence of the terminal. So I had redirected both streams to os devnul. Little did I know that os.devnull was a string, not a file descriptor, and I needed to open() it to get the file descriptor.

values.message:
Fixed a bug where printing to stdout and stderr would cause a crash because both streams were apparently a string ('nul').

This was caused because when running without a command window, all output is redirected to os.devnull to prevent the stupid windows crash where you cant write to stdout in the absence of the terminal. So I had redirected both streams to os devnul. Little did I know that os.devnull was a string, not a file descriptor, and I needed to open() it to get the file descriptor.

message.raw:
Fixed issue where sometimes the event arguments wouldn't be in the event_args list when their event was processed.
This was fixed by putting the args into the list before the corresponding event is added to the event queue. Now the arguments will always be ready by the time the event is processed.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug in the pulseblaster class where init_done and static_mode where being set to True before initialisation events were complete.

This was causing program events to be handled before initialisation was done, which was repeatedly crashing the pulseblaster tab.

Still seeing an error happen periodically where the pulseblaster mainloop dies in g07a. At least restart now works...

Also doing the first commit of the G07a connection table!

message.raw:
The error message drop-down panel thing is now a pane, so that it can be resized to view more errors.

This was motivated by the copious amounts of errors that sometimes spew from the PulseBlaster and friends.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where restarting failed when the mainloop was waiting for a the next event.
This was a regression from when we changed the passing of arguments not to use the event_queue. The instruction to the mainloop to quit still did use the event queue, and so it failed.

Also made the error fontsize a bit bigger. It was kinda small.

Also made the error fontsize a bit bigger. It was kinda small.

message.raw:
Now performs checks that the user isn't passing unserialisable objects from parent to the child or vice-versa, and fails gracefully in either case.
Also, fixed a bug where errors weren't escaped for markup before being added to markup (for red colour and monospace font). This caused a crash for errors with some characters. Now they are escaped properly with cgi.escape()

Also, fixed a bug where errors weren't escaped for markup before being added to markup (for red colour and monospace font). This caused a crash for errors with some characters. Now they are escaped properly with cgi.escape()

message.raw:
You can now pass pickleable or unpickleable objects to the worker class at its initialisation, by passing a dictionary workerargs, for eg workerargs={'x':Queue(),'y':'foobar'} to the Tab class initialisation.

The worker object will then have x and y added as instance variables self.x and self.y.

This was motivated by the requirement to pass an extra Queue object to the worker process of the NI card.

Also if you do try to pass unpickleable objects to the worker later, you used to get a hard crash. Now the worker simply stops responding, and a reset works fine. I don't seem to be able to catch the exception -- it doesn't appear to happen in either the parent or child exceptions! So I'll make this better at some point by checking first that all objects are pickleable before passing them.
message.html:
You can now pass pickleable or unpickleable objects to the worker class at its initialisation, by passing a dictionary workerargs, for eg workerargs={'x':Queue(),'y':'foobar'} to the Tab class initialisation.

The worker object will then have x and y added as instance variables self.x and self.y.

This was motivated by the requirement to pass an extra Queue object to the worker process of the NI card.

Also if you do try to pass unpickleable objects to the worker later, you used to get a hard crash. Now the worker simply stops responding, and a reset works fine. I don't seem to be able to catch the exception -- it doesn't appear to happen in either the parent or child exceptions! So I'll make this better at some point by checking first that all objects are pickleable before passing them.

summary.raw:
You can now pass pickleable or unpickleable objects to the worker class at its initialisation, by passing a dictionary workerargs, for eg workerargs={'x':Queue(),'y':'foobar'} to the Tab class initialisation.

The worker object will then have x and y added as instance variables self.x and self.y.

This was motivated by the requirement to pass an extra Queue object to the worker process of the NI card.

Also if you do try to pass unpickleable objects to the worker later, you used to get a hard crash. Now the worker simply stops responding, and a reset works fine. So I'll make this better at some point by checking first that all objects are pickleable before passing them.
summary.html:
You can now pass pickleable or unpickleable objects to the worker class at its initialisation, by passing a dictionary workerargs, for eg workerargs={'x':Queue(),'y':'foobar'} to the Tab class initialisation.

The worker object will then have x and y added as instance variables self.x and self.y.

This was motivated by the requirement to pass an extra Queue object to the worker process of the NI card.

Also if you do try to pass unpickleable objects to the worker later, you used to get a hard crash. Now the worker simply stops responding, and a reset works fine. I don't seem to be able to catch the exception -- it doesn't appear to happen in either the parent or child exceptions! So I'll make this better at some point by checking first that all objects are pickleable before passing them.

values.message:
You can now pass pickleable or unpickleable objects to the worker class at its initialisation, by passing a dictionary workerargs, for eg workerargs={'x':Queue(),'y':'foobar'} to the Tab class initialisation.

The worker object will then have x and y added as instance variables self.x and self.y.

This was motivated by the requirement to pass an extra Queue object to the worker process of the NI card.

Also if you do try to pass unpickleable objects to the worker later, you used to get a hard crash. Now the worker simply stops responding, and a reset works fine. I don't seem to be able to catch the exception -- it doesn't appear to happen in either the parent or child exceptions! So I'll make this better at some point by checking first that all objects are pickleable before passing them.

message.raw:
Changed 'unhandled error' to 'fatal error' since sometimes the user will want to intentionally raise an error indicating a fatal condition, and calling this 'unhandled' is a little misleading.
This is motivated by the PulseBlaster -- if it's status isn't as expected, then the problem is handled by intentionally raising a fatal exception.

message.raw:
Now have a function to add timeouts: tab.statemachine_timeout_add(delay, function, *args,*kwargs).

It will queue up a state function (one which has been decorated with @define_event) to the state machine, and then once the function has been executed, it will queue it up again after delay. It will repeat this until the function is removed from tab.timeouts.
Also, tabs are now reorderable :)

Also, tabs are now reorderable :)

message.raw: Fixed bug where restarting would break because there was no element in self.event_args when the mainloop pulled the signal to restart out of the event queue. Now it only looks for args after it's already worked out that it's not going to restart.

message.raw: Loggging! Device Tabs and workers now both have logger objects (self.logger) with which you can logger.debug('some message') all you like, and see the output in a terminal or a log file. The log lines automatically have the name of the device and whether its the worker or not, so you won't have to be figuring out where your print lines are coming from.

message.raw:
Fixed issue with the tab_base_class.

Since subclassing tab_base_classes overrides the init method, the restart method in the base class needs to pass the parameters needed to reinitialise the subclass (novatechdds9m).

Thus the easiest solution is to make both the superclass and subclass __init__ methods take the same parameters!
message.html:
Fixed issue with the tab_base_class.

Since subclassing tab_base_classes overrides the init method, the restart method in the base class needs to pass the parameters needed to reinitialise the subclass (novatechdds9m).

Thus the easiest solution is to make both the superclass and subclass init methods take the same parameters!

summary.raw:
Fixed issue with the tab_base_class.

Since subclassing tab_base_classes overrides the init method, the restart method in the base class needs to pass the parameters needed to reinitialise the subclass (novatechdds9m).

Thus the easiest solution is to make both the superclass and subclass __init__ methods take the same parameters!
summary.html:
Fixed issue with the tab_base_class.

Since subclassing tab_base_classes overrides the init method, the restart method in the base class needs to pass the parameters needed to reinitialise the subclass (novatechdds9m).

Thus the easiest solution is to make both the superclass and subclass init methods take the same parameters!

values.message:
Fixed issue with the tab_base_class.

Since subclassing tab_base_classes overrides the init method, the restart method in the base class needs to pass the parameters needed to reinitialise the subclass (novatechdds9m).

Thus the easiest solution is to make both the superclass and subclass __init__ methods take the same parameters!

message.raw:
The event queue for the main process now stores the arguments in a normal list, so that things can be passed by reference, including unpicklable objects that were being unnecessarily serialised to be put into the queue.
It quickly became apparent that only being able to pass serialisable things would be a problem, since GTK callbacks of course pass references to widgets around. Since this isn't IPC we're talking about, there's no reason to serialise these things.

Also, errors now queue up until dismissed. So you wont just see the most recent error if several occur in a row, you'll see all of them, in order, with timestamps. They display in a scrolled window.
message.html:
The event queue for the main process now stores the arguments in a normal list, so that things can be passed by reference, including unpicklable objects that were being unnecessarily serialised to be put into the queue.
It quickly became apparent that only being able to pass serialisable things would be a problem, since GTK callbacks of course pass references to widgets around. Since this isn't IPC we're talking about, there's no reason to serialise these things.

Also, errors now queue up until dismissed. So you wont just see the most recent error if several occur in a row, you'll see all of them, in order, with timestamps. They display in a scrolled window.

values.message:
The event queue for the main process now stores the arguments in a normal list, so that things can be passed by reference, including unpicklable objects that were being unnecessarily serialised to be put into the queue.
It quickly became apparent that only being able to pass serialisable things would be a problem, since GTK callbacks of course pass references to widgets around. Since this isn't IPC we're talking about, there's no reason to serialise these things.

Also, errors now queue up until dismissed. So you wont just see the most recent error if several occur in a row, you'll see all of them, in order, with timestamps. They display in a scrolled window.

message.raw:
Some refactoring.

Replaced threads_enter and threads_leave with gtk.gdk.lock context manager.

Put do_stuff function into the HTTPRequestHandler thread and renamed it to process_request.

Made imports more explicit and ordered by convention as to what is a standard library module, what's a 3rd party and what's ours.

Deleted some unused imports and a commented out method.

(Requires testing on windows before its at all clear that these changes worked!)

message.raw: Made child processes daemonic, so they quit when the parent does (ie when BLACS quits completely). Connected gtk.main_quit to the close button of the main window in the demo code to simulate this. Now when you  click the close button, everything actually cleanly quits, no dangling threads or orphaned processes.
message.html: Made child processes daemonic, so they quit when the parent does (ie when BLACS quits completely). Connected gtk.main_quit to the close button of the main window in the demo code to simulate this. Now when you click the close button, everything actually cleanly quits, no dangling threads or orphaned processes.

values.message: Made child processes daemonic, so they quit when the parent does (ie when BLACS quits completely). Connected gtk.main_quit to the close button of the main window in the demo code to simulate this. Now when you  click the close button, everything actually cleanly quits, no dangling threads or orphaned processes.

Handles a subprocess and a main process, catches errors in both and displays them, allows for the whole thing to be restarted in the event of a crash... read the comments for more info!

message.raw:
Successfully decoupled the static programming from the updating of the GUI.

This is one of the important steps to moving ALL hardware programming to a separate process (leading to a very very robust system. Effectively BLACS will be as good as Google Chrome, just replace web page tabs with hardware device tabs!)

message.raw:
Appending data at end of acquisition is now very fast!

Writing to h5file is the slowest part.

Can handle 32 channels @ 20kHz for 120s.
Can't handle the same for 180s. I catch an exception, but there is no error message. Might be to do with the size of the numpy array? May have to split, and write consecutive numpy arrays to the h5 file

message.raw:
Modified data acquisition on ni_pcie_6363. We now append data to an array at the end of the experiment (due to performance issues).

Unfortunately with 32 channels @ 20kHz for 60s results in a 3 minute wait while the array is formed at the end of the experiment.

We're working to resolve this ASAP!

message.raw:
Added connection object (a sample connection table is added to the SVN here)
Successfully matches against another connection table, and returns whether the other table is a subset of the main one.

We will use this to check that submitted h5 files have a connection table that is valid within the context of the current experiment connection table. Ones that don't pass the test will be rejected.

This protects somewhat against people submitting jobs to the wrong machine, or trying to submit jobs to a machine that isn't configured for their experiment.
message.html:
Added connection object (a sample connection table is added to the SVN here)
Successfully matches against another connection table, and returns whether the other table is a subset of the main one.

We will use this to check that submitted h5 files have a connection table that is valid within the context of the current experiment connection table. Ones that don't pass the test will be rejected.

This protects somewhat against people submitting jobs to the wrong machine, or trying to submit jobs to a machine that isn't configured for their experiment.
